Unfortunately there are some build failures but they seem to be all unrelated (scala, some github issue with cub etc). They seem to pop up by today when I incorporated the latest MXNet code. Eric, can you take a look? May be you have an idea. Has something pushed recently that explains that?

Summary of the changes:

- Added a set of BLAS3/LAPACK based operators. This set is rich enough to support a set of interesting linear algebra applications including Gaussian processes (standalone or integrated with deep learning strategies for parameter estimation). There is already interest from several other sides specifically on the Cholesky factorization. 
- The operators are currently avail only for CPU but we are working on GPU support already and are committed to supply it based on cuSolver.
- For the LAPACK operators (potrf,potri), a low level MXNet-specific abstraction has been implemented that enable us to switch the underlying LAPACK integration easily without going through the entire MXNet code. This abstraction currently supports only potrf/potri but can be extended easily whenever there is the need to make more lapack-functions available. 
- This low level abstraction is currently just for CPU. We may combine GPU and CPU together into a higher level abstraction when bringing in GPU-support.
- The LAPACK-abstraction interfaces directly with the core Fortran-libraries on all platforms. This is the only consistent way as C-wrappers for lapack differ heavily between platforms and all lapack-packages that are relevant for us (and likely all other ones as well) use anyway the underlying Fortran library.  This is also the way numpy integrates lapack (just that numpy uses an extra utility to generate the C-declarations from the fortran library automatically). 
- Above method should be stable as the LAPACK-fortran interfaces are unlikely to change ever.
- All of the usual BLAS-packages that we integrate with MXNet (openblas,apple,atlas,mkl) include lapack already by default. Smaller differences: On Ubuntu, the lapack library is not installed automatically with openblas, it must be installed explicitly. On Windows, blas and lapack are mangled into a single library. apple/atlas/mkl contain lapack  automatically. When using openblas, we have to add a linker flag to include liblapack. Makefiles, configuration files etc have been updated accordingly, also the installation documentation. 

- Whenever MXNet is compiled with one of the BLAS libraries openblas/atlas/mkl/apple as well as for all compiles on windows, a compiler flag -DMXNET_USE_LAPACK is set that will activate the LAPACK-abstraction in the C++ code and add the lapack library to the linker step (if necessary for the platform). If the compiler flag is not present, then dummy stubs will be generated in the C++ abstraction  that will cause a runtime error with appropriate error message whenever a lapack-function is called. This ensures that MXNET can always be compiled even when no lapack is available. Though as lapack will likely become soon a vital part of MXNet and is also available on all platforms, I think we will only use that for some potential special "lightweight" builds. 

Once again, I would be happy if someone else can look into the mysterious build errors. I got all compiled clean before but now they pop up.

Subject: [dmlc/mxnet] MKL Breaking Existing Functionality (#6615)


Building against MKL-DNN breaks certain existing functionality. For example: the Activation symbol with "relu" crashes during a forward pass whenever the rank of the input is not 4.

Are there any other areas where linking against MKL-DNN breaks existing functionality? And is this expected behaviour, or is this a bug?

```r
require(mxnet)
#===============Example Data=================
dataGen <- function(a,b,c,d,e){data <- as.logical(c(round(runif(9000)-a,0),
                                                    round(runif(9000)-b,0),
                                                    round(runif(9000)-c,0),
                                                    round(runif(9000)-d,0),
                                                    round(runif(9000)-e,0)))
return(data)}

class0 <-dataGen(.1,.1,.5,.1,-.2)
class1 <-dataGen(.1,.4,.5,-.4,.1)
class2 <-dataGen(.5,-.1,.2,-.1,.1)
train.array <- rbind(class0,class1,class2)

#we want 3000 tensors of width 3 height 3 and depth 5
dim(train.array) <- c(3,3,5,3000)

train.y <- as.array(c(rep(0,1000),rep(1,1000),rep(2,1000)))


trainIter = mx.io.arrayiter(data = train.array, label = train.y)


#===============Symbolic Model=================
data <- mx.symbol.Variable(name='data')
#first conv
conv1 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, num_filter=50, kernel=c(1,1,5))
relu1 <- mx.symbol.LeakyReLU(data=conv1)
#second conv
conv2 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data=relu1, num_filter=30, kernel=c(2,2,1))
relu2 <- mx.symbol.LeakyReLU(data=conv2)
#flat
flatten <- mx.symbol.Flatten(data=relu2)
fc <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=300)
drop2 <- mx.symbol.Dropout(data=fc,p=.5)
#final fullc
fcOut <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=drop2, num_hidden=3)
myNet <- mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(fcOut)

#===============Generate Solver================
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(symbol=myNet,
                                     array.layout='auto',
                                     X=trainIter,
                                     ctx=mx.cpu(),
                                     num.round=100, 
                                     wd=0.00001,
                                     initializer=mx.init.Xavier(),
                                     eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy,
                                     learning.rate=0.01, 
                                     optimizer = 'adagrad',
                                     verbose = T)
```

The solution is to create a custom metric with a defined threshold. In this example, I set the threshold to 0.5.
```
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
import logging
import sys
logging.basicConfig(stream = sys.stdout, level = logging.DEBUG)

data = np.random.random((1000, 100))
label = np.random.randint(2, size = (1000, 1))

train_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data = data,
                               label = label,
                               data_name = 'data',
                               label_name = 'label',
                               batch_size = 32,
                               shuffle = True)

data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
label = mx.symbol.Variable('label')
fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = data, num_hidden = 32)
act = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, act_type = 'relu')
fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act, num_hidden = 1)
logits = mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data = fc2, label = label)

# Custom metric with threshold set to 0.5
metric = mx.metric.CustomMetric(feval = lambda labels, pred: ((pred > 0.5) == labels).mean(),
                                name = "acc") 

model = mx.mod.Module(symbol = logits,
                      data_names = ['data'],
                      label_names = ['label'],
                      context = mx.gpu(0))

model.fit(train_data = train_iter,
          optimizer = 'rmsprop',
          eval_metric = metric,
          num_epoch = 10)
```

Try this
```
library(mxnet)
library(magrittr)
mx.set.seed(0)

LR <- mx.symbol.Variable("data") %>%
  mx.symbol.FullyConnected(num_hidden = 1) %>%
  mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput()

train.x <- data.matrix(dades[, 1])
train.y <- dades[, 2]

metric <- mx.metric.custom("acc", function(label, pred) {
 mean((pred > 0.5) == label)
})
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(LR, 
                                     X = train.x, 
                                     y = train.y,
                                     ctx = mx.cpu(), 
                                     num.round = 10, 
                                     array.batch.size = 100,
                                     learning.rate = 0.0001, 
                                     momentum = 0.4, 
                                     eval.metric = metric,
                                     array.layout = 'rowmajor')

pred <- predict(model, train.x, array.layout = 'rowmajor')
pred <- as.numeric((pred > 0.5) == train.y)
confusion_matrix <- table(pred, train.y)
sum(diag(confusion_matrix)) / sum(confusion_matrix)
```

@umichyiwan @happygds 
You need to give param_idx2name to optimizer.
```
lr_dict = dict()
param_idx2name = dict()
for idx, arg_name in enumerate(arg_names):
    lr_dict[arg_name] = 1.0
    param_idx2name[idx] = arg_name

optimizer = mx.optimizer.Adam(args.lr, sym = sym, param_idx2name=param_idx2name, rescale_grad = 1.0 / args.batch_size)
optimizer.set_lr_mult(lr_dict)
```

Then, _get_lr() takes index by name accurately as @umichyiwan mentioned.

Besides, the first input variable is `prefix`, not full name. For example, there're two files named `resnet-50-symbol.json` and `resnet-50-0000.params`. Be careful the `prefix` name.
````Python
prefix = 'resnet-50'
epoch = 0
sym, arg_params, aux_params = mx.model.load_checkpoint(prefix, epoch)
````

I simplified the code so it will be easier to understand the situation (consider to change your example above):
```r
# Generate testing data
train.x = matrix(data = rexp(120*6380, rate = 10), nrow = 120, ncol = 6380)
train.y = matrix(data = rexp(120*319, rate = 10), nrow = 120, ncol = 319)

# Define the input data
data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
# Define the first fully connected layer
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, num_hidden = 319)
# Customize loss function
label <- mx.symbol.Variable("label")
lro <- mx.symbol.MakeLoss(mx.symbol.Correlation(fc1 ,label))

model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(symbol=lro, 
                                     X=t(train.x), 
                                     y=t(train.x),
```

So `apt-get install libopenblas-dev` won't install lapack? In that case we probably should add an USE_LAPACK option in config.mk and turn it off by default for openblas.

Also maybe we should turn off lapack for amalgamation. How big is lapack lib?

This is because concat doesn't do backward shape inference yet. You can verify it by grouping y3 and c, then do infer_shape_partial. You'll see y3 is still empty.

it can be fixed by adding backward shape infer to concat. Would you like to propose a fix?

RuntimeError: simple_bind error. Arguments:
lin_reg_label: (150,)
data: (150, 9723L, 3)
Error in operator lro: Shape inconsistent, Provided=(150,), inferred shape=(150,2)


This means when num_hidden=2, your label should be (150, 2) instead of (150,)

The tutorials are MXNet concepts that are best understood when you go over step by step either using a notebook or using the Python interpreter. You don't achieve the intended goal if the user just runs from top to bottom. If we have to make the .py file experience better by adding print statements, etc., it will clutter the tutorial with unnecessary code.

This was probably provided to allow users copy paste the code. We already have that ability on the website. They can also download the entire file as .py file from jupyter.

`infer_partial_shape` not raising exceptions doesn't mean the shape inference is completed without problems. In the backend, `infer_partial_shape` and `infer_shape` do the same thing, except that `infer_partial_shape` would return shape inference results even though some shapes cannot be inferred, while `infer_shape` would print error messages (what shapes cannot be inferred) and return `None`. simple_bind needs complete shape inference results to continue.
And there will still be only one loss function?

So  I managed to use the correlation with this code:

```r
require(mxnet)
A = mx.symbol.Variable('A')
B = mx.symbol.Variable('B')
C = mx.symbol.Correlation(A,B,kernel_size = 1,max_displacement = 1,stride1 = 1,stride2 = 1
                          ,pad_size = 4,is_multiply = FALSE)
#C = mx.symbol.sort(A+B)
a = mx.nd.reshape(mx.nd.zeros(c(4), mx.cpu()),shape=c(1,1,1,4))
b = mx.nd.reshape(mx.nd.array(as.array(c(7, 2,4,5)), mx.cpu()),shape=c(1,1,1,4))

exec = mxnet:::mx.symbol.bind(
  symbol=C,
  ctx=mx.cpu(),
  arg.arrays = list(A=a, B=b),
  aux.arrays = list(),
  grad.reqs = list("null", "null"))

# calculate outputs
mx.exec.forward(exec)
out = as.array(exec$outputs[[1]])
print(out)
```

However, as you can see from the result this is not a simple correlation of two arrays.

@piiswrong we should improve the process of PRs being tested, it's been discussed in the past and we can have another discussion later.  There are multiple people working to make sure the tutorials work seamlessly on the platforms that MXNet supports, so you see multiple PRs. let's move these opinion based discussions to slack channel in the future.

So, 2 things:
 - existence of winograd kernels means that you do training - are you sure you want to do that vs just inference on Tegra?
 - the calls you see in the fp16 case are pseudo-fp16 calls (input/output is in fp16, but the math is actually done in fp32), so it is understandable that you get similar perf for them. I was under impression that setting MSHADOW_USE_PASCAL flag during compilation should do calls to true-fp16 versions. Are you sure you set that flag?

this particular results were obtained using TX1. MSHADOW_USE_PASCAL=0 in this case, as I assumed this has to be set to 1 only for TX2.
this is how I run the mxnet
sym = resnet.get_symbol(num_classes=10,num_layers=18,image_shape=image_shape)
mod = mx.mod.Module(symbol=sym, context=mx.gpu(device_id))
mod.bind(for_training=False, inputs_need_grad=False, data_shapes=[('data', (batch_size,3,Y,X))])
...
d = mx.nd.array(d,mx.gpu(device_id))
Batch = namedtuple('Batch', ['data'])
mod.forward(Batch([d]))

running the same way on TX2 compiled with MSHADOW_USE_PASCAL=1 shows no difference either

I retract my comment about training - I looked at the profiles and you are doing only inference in those runs.

"running the same way" means "it does not give a speed difference too" or "I profiled it and also see pseudofp16 versions of kernels"? Please do the profile.

Adding @DickJC123, since he was experimenting a lot with pseudo- vs true-fp16 paths in MXNet. I assumed that setting MSHADOW_USE_PASCAL should give true-fp16 kernels. Is that not true?
